Speaker: notable
Dialogue: An honor, Mrs. Teasdale...  You must indeed have great faith in your new dictator to give him such a magnificent reception.

Speaker: servant
Dialogue: His Excellency, Ambassador Verdi Trentino of Amnesia!

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Mrs. Teasdale... my niece, Vera.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Mrs. Teasdale, for you -- I would do anything.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Mrs. Teasdale -- no matter who rules Freedonia, to me you will always be the first lady of the land.

Speaker: vera
Dialogue: Mrs. Teasdale, my uncle's hopeless -- you've been the only topic of conversation ever since we left Amnesia.

Speaker: servant
Dialogue: The Honorable Mohamed Pandooh of Mufhtan!

Speaker: vera
Dialogue: So that's the one you want to marry.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: With Mrs. Teasdale as my wife and Freedonia under my control --

Speaker: vera
Dialogue: Maybe it's not going to be so easy. From what I've heard, Mrs. Teasdale is rather sweet on this Rufus T. Firefly.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: That's where you come in.  I'll leave him in your hands, and don't forget you're supposed to be my niece.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Isn't it about time for the ceremony to begin, Mrs. Teasdale?  I do hope His Excellency won't be late.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: My father makes it a point to always be on time.  As long as I've known him, he's never been late for an appointment.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: But it's two minutes of ten now.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: His Excellency is due To take his station.  Beginning his new Administration...  He'll make his appearance when The clock on the wall strikes ten.

Speaker: all
Dialogue: Hail, hail, Freedonia...  Mightiest of mighty nations!  Hail, hail, Freedonia Land of the brave and free.

Speaker: all
Dialogue: Hail, hail, Freedonia... Land of the brave and free.

Speaker: all
Dialogue: Hail, hail, Freedonia... Land of the brave and free.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Mrs. Teasdale, I assure you there is nothing to worry about.  Father is probably taking extra care in getting into his robes of state.  I'll call him.

Speaker: all
Dialogue: Hail, hail, Freedonia... Land of the brave and free.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Never mind that stuff...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Take a card.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: You can keep it -- I've got a whole pack...  Now what were you saying?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: How late do you stay open?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Well, I won't stand for much.  And I won't stand for you if you don't show some improvement soon.  Look at your report card last month -- "D" in spelling...  six in behavior. Now who were the six?  A fine state of affairs -- no wonder you can't matriculate, now what were you saying?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Not that I care -- but where is your husband?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: No wonder he passed away.  I'd like to be with you to the very end. Can't you see what I'm trying to tell you -- I love you.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: You're not so bad yourself, Mrs. Teasdale, when I look at you I can see that we're facing a crisis. We've got to balance the budget -- we've got to cut down everything including, you.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Thanks... but I can't stay very long.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: That's even a greater honor.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: I bring you the greetings of my President and the good will of my people.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: I'll keep the greetings -- but you can send back the good will... what we need right now is twenty million dollars.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Twenty million dollars is a considerable sum...  I'll have to discuss that with my Minister of Finance.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Well, in the meantime, could you let me have $50 personally?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: I'll tell you what I'll do.  I'll give you Mrs. Teasdale as security.  or my jackknife.  If you want my advice, you'll take the jackknife... I've a better proposition...  Make it $25 and I'll give you a first mortgage on my son and I hope you foreclose.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Your Excellency, haven't we met before?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Why yes.  I met you at the dog races -- say, you could have won that race if you tried a little harder.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Excellency, may I present my niece.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Go ahead.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: You don't understand.  This is my niece Vera.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: And Vera niece, too.

Speaker: vera
Dialogue: Your Excellency, please don't think me silly, but I'd love to have a picture of you.  I want to hang it in my bedroom.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: You couldn't hang me in your bedroom -- I'll make a note of it.  Where's my secretary?

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Here I am, Father.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Take a letter.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Who to?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: The President of the United States.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: My dear President...  read it back...

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: "My dear President"...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: That doesn't sound right...  take out "President"...  now read it.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: "My dear"...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: That's not right yet... put back "President" and take out "dear"... How does it read now?

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: "My President"...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: There's still something wrong with it... take out "President" ...now what've you got?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Now we're on the right track... Put back "dear"... How does it read?

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: "My dear"...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: You can't say that to the President... Put back "President"... Now let's hear how sounds.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: "My dear President"...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: That's what I wanted in the first place.  Tear it up and send it airmail.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Is that all?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Take another letter...  to my tailor.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Dear Sir... enclosed find check for $100.  Yours very truly...  Send that immediately.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: I'll have to enclose the check first.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: You do and I'll fire you.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Well, a gal a day is enough for me. I couldn't handle any more.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: These are the laws of my administration: No one's allowed to smoke or tell a dirty joke -- And whistling is forbidden...

Speaker: ensemble
Dialogue: We're not allowed to tell a dirty joke HAIL, HAIL, FREEDONIA

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: If chewing gum is chewed, The chewer is pursued And in the hoosegow hidden...

Speaker: ensemble
Dialogue: If we should choose to chew, we'll be pursued -

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: If any form of pleasure is exhibited Report to me and it will be prohibited.  I'll put my foot down; So shall it be - This is the land of the free.  The last man nearly ruined this place He didn't know what to do with it.  If you think this country's bad off now Just wait 'till I get through with it.

Speaker: dignitary
Dialogue: In our midst you stand The ruler of this land A man who'll govern with an iron hand.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: If anyone gets fresh with me, I'll show him who's the boss; I'll stand upon my dignity, And toss him for a loss.  And this will be the penalty For those who doublecross - We'll stand 'em up against the wall, and Pop goes the Weasel

Speaker: ensemble
Dialogue: If you should make him cross, He'll toss you for a loss.  If anyone gets fresh with him, He'll show him who's the boss.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: I will not stand for anything that's crooked or unfair; I'm strictly on the up and up, So everyone beware. If anyone's caught taking graft And I don't get my share, we'll stand 'em up against the wall - and pop goes the weasel!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: If any man should come between A husband and his bride, We find out which one she prefers By letting her decide.  If she prefers the other man, The husband steps outside; We stand him up against the wall And Pop goes the Weasel!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: The population must increase With great rapidity.  We give a couple seven years To raise a family. If, by that time, there is no branch Upon the family tree, we stand 'em up against the wall - and Pop goes the Weasel.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: That's what I get for dressing in a hurry.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: I wrote a speech last night that'll knock them off their seats...  Four score and seven years ago, our fathers brought forth on this continent a new nation --

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: He did?... I told my son not to leave it laying around... Where is son?

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Here I am, Father...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Send for my car...

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: His Excellency's car!

Speaker: guards
Dialogue: His Excellency's car!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: To the House of Representatives... ride like fury... Don't stop for any signals and don't wait for a corner to make a turn... see if you can break a record...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: A fine thing -- leaving the head of the nation at the foot of the stairs...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: That concludes the nine o'clock sprints... Next Saturday night the winner of the six day bicycle race will receive ten thousand dollars in gold... the following morning we go off the gold standard...

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: Gentlemen, gentlemen, remember for forty-six years we have enjoyed the friendship of Amnesia, so ably represented by Ambassador Trentino.  We owe it to ourselves to listen to what he has to say...

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Gentlemen, while I admit it is unusual for a representative of one country to advise the legislative body of another, I assure you that I have the interest of Freedonia at heart ...  We have lent you money in the past -- we are willing to lend you money again -- but, we cannot do it if your leader is allowed by you, to carry out his ridiculous proposals... In self-protection it is my --

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: I object!...  we have no right to discuss this matter in the absence of my father.

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: We have been meeting every morning for eight days and not once has His Excellency been on time...

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Gentlemen, I cannot wait much longer...

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: Would you mind calling your father again?

Speaker: members
Dialogue: HAIL, HAIL, FREEDONIA Land of the brave and free...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: What's to stop you from digging one... And after you dig a river, how're ya gonna cross it without a bridge...? We've got to have a bridge to stop people from going places -- then we've gotta stop them from coming back.  If you're worried about the expense we can have a bridge with only one end -- and if that's a success we can do away with it altogether. I'm telling you that what this country needs is --

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: If there's one thing we don't need right now -- it's peanuts -- gentlemen, what good is a bridge if you haven't got ammunition to blow it up... ammunition was never cheaper...  Right now, you can get two cannons for the price of one and shoot twice as far for half the money...  With every five thousand dollar purchase we throw in a Big Bertha... If you don't like her, you can throw her right out again.  I tell you no country can protect itself without --

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: I'm sorry your Excellency, it is that infernal peanut vendor Chicolini... How can we accomplish anything with that constant annoyance?

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Your Excellency - are we or are we not going to discuss this problem - my time is valuable - I'm a man of few words -

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: I'm a man of one word... SCRAM!!!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Go out and chase that peanut vendor away from the building -- Get rid of him if you have to use violence - if necessary call out the militia and if he isn't looking get me a bag of peanuts.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: I've tried to chase him but it's no use - he won't go -

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: He won't eh? - We'll see about that - send for your father immediately.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: But you're my father -

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Never mind then, I'll get in touch with him myself -

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: "P-E-A-N-U-T-S"

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: How'm I doing, boss?

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Fine - keep on yelling - Do everything you can to disturb Firefly - Now what about your cousin?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: He's working very hard - I got him a job driving Firefly's car - He's-a driving him crazy and I'm driving him nuts - P-E-A-N-U-T-S

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: I'll get rid of that pest - watch me --

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Hey you!!

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: All right -

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Have you got a license?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: No, but my dog he's a got millions of them --

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: What kind of a dog is he?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: He used to be a bloodhound but he's anemic --

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Well - what is he now?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: He's half poodle and half watch dog -

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Half watch dog?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Yeh, he's only got one eye.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: I don't know much about dogs but you ought to be on the end of a leash - a ninety-nine year leash -  Look - what do you call your dog?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: I don't call him, I whistle.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: What do you whistle?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Yankee Poodle.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: I've got just the place for a man like you but I'm too busy right now to do any digging.  What do you call your dog when you want him?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: I don't want him.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Well, if you don't want your dog why don't you put him in a pound?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: He only weighs ten ounces --

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: I can use you in the House of Representatives.  We need a man who understands dogs -- and that's where this country is going to.  Step inside.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: In case of fire, how long will it take to empty this place?

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: About - thirty-four seconds.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: We'll start a fire --  -- and get rid of these microbes.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Hello!...  Yes...  Yes...  He's not in...

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: That was for you.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: I'm sorry I'm not in.  I wanted to have a long talk with you...  Now look here, my good man, you've got to stop yelling "peanuts" in front of the House of Representatives.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Oh no, I can't do it.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: You don't want to be a public nuisance, do you?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Sure.  How much does the job pay?  Sure, if there's a chance for advancement.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: You wouldn't consider going over Niagara Falls without a barrel?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: 'At's-a no good.  I went to Niagara Falls once.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Did you shoot the rapids?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: No, but I shot some ducks.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: If there was an open season for fellows like you, I'd get myself a hunting license.   Anyway, I'm going to make you a sporting proposition. You give up the peanut stand and I'll make you vice-president of the country.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Oh, no -- nothing doing.  I had a brother who was a vice-president once and that's the last we ever heard of him.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Well, maybe he's still the vice- president.  Now if I were to offer you --

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: That was for you again.  He wants you to call him up as soon as you get back.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: I don't know what's keeping me.  I should've been here a long time ago. Now how about my proposition?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: What other job you got?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Let's see -- What've I got in my cabinet besides mice --  I've got it -- how would you like to be Secretary of the Interior?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: That's no good.  I like to work on the outside.  I must have something easy.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Then you don't wanna work hard?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: I don't wanna work at all.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: In that case you'll have to take a civil service examination --  if you pass I'll put you in the post-office -- stick out your tongue.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: I don't wanna stick out my tongue.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Well, if you wanna work in the post- office you'll have to stick out your tongue.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Look, I'm a very nervous man.  I gotta have a job where I come to work at eleven -- go to lunch at twelve -- and quit at one.  And twice a year I gotta have a six month vacation.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: I've got just the job for you -- Secretary of War.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: 'At's-a fine.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: You know, I'd be lost without a telephone.  Now - where were we? Oh, yes - I just made you Secretary of War.  The first thing you do is buy ammunition -- you buy it from me and I get 10% commission.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: What do I get?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: You get half mine and I get half yours.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: I don't want to buy ammunition -- we no gotta war.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Then we've gotta start one. Do you know how to start a war?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Sure, that's easy.  You gotta insult somebody.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: My card.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: I come from one country.  You come from another country.  I say something you don't like.  You say something I don't like - and I'm insulted.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Why wasn't I insulted?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: You was insulted, but you don't know it.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Then I demand an apology!

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: That's a-no good.  If I apologize we no got a war.  Look -- I send you a scrap of paper.  You send me a scrap of paper -- and we have a scrap.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: You've got a brain after all - and how you get along without it is amazing to me -- Now, who can I insult?...  Who do we owe money to?...  AMBASSADOR TRENTINO!  How about him?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: He's-a very easy to insult --  I say something to his niece once, and he slapped my face.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Why didn't his niece slap your face?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: She did.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: What did you say to her?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: You're lucky I don't slap your face -- you oughtta be ashamed of yourself. Where did you hear that story?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: You told it to me.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Oh, yes, I remember -- and I should have slapped Mrs. Teasdale's face when she told it to me... I'm going right out and find Trentino.  You go right out and get yourself an army.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Wait a minute.  What kind of an army do you think we oughtta have?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: I think we oughtta have a standing army, so we can save money on chairs.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: To Mrs. Teasdale's residence!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: This is the fifth trip I've made today and I haven't been anywhere yet.

Speaker: guard's voice
Dialogue: His Excellency, Rufus T. Firefly!

Speaker: guests
Dialogue: HAIL, HAIL, FREEDONIA Land of the brave and free...

Speaker: trentino's voice
Dialogue: Can't you see, Gloria, our marriage would not only unite two great families...

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: ...but would further cement the relations of our countries.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Oh.  Then there his somebody else?

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Can't you see that I'm at your feet?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Gloria, I love you.  I --

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Can't we go some place where we can be alone?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: ...but we can have a little family of our own.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: All I can offer you is a Rufus over your head.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: I wouldn't know what to say either if I was in your place.  Maybe you can suggest something.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: This has gone far enough!  This interruption is humiliating, to say the least...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Well, why not say the least and get it over with?

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: I didn't come here to be insulted.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: That's what you think.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: You swine!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Give me that again!

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: You worm!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Once more!

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: You upstart!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: That's it!  No man lives who can call a Firefly an upstart.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Touch.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Mrs. Teasdale,  I feel this regrettable occurrence will plunge our countries into war.

Speaker: vera
Dialogue: Uncle, you can't do this!

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: My dear niece -- I must ask you not to interfere.  War is not a woman's problem.

Speaker: vera
Dialogue: It is every woman's problem.  Who supplies the sons? -- the brothers? -- the husbands?  Who...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: You keep that up and you'll crab the whole war.

Speaker: vera
Dialogue: Carry out this tragic folly if you will -- But I for one will not be a part of it.  I will stay here in Freedonia.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: My country has spoken.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Then it's war?

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: How're ya fixed for ammunition?

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Bah!!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: THEN IT'S WAR!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: THEN IT'S WAR!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: GATHER THE FORCES!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: HARNESS THE HORSES!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: THEN IT'S WAR!

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: The Secretary of War will see you next, Miss.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Did you hear the one about the woman taking a bath?... Well, she forgot to lock the door... A man came in and said, "I'm a doctor"... The woman said, "I'm not sick"... and the man said, "that's all right.  I'm not a doctor."

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Look!

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: You look pretty good to me - but very still need a spy - Have you got any credentials?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: You got credentials all right.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: This is fine.  Put it back.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: I think I better take another look at that paper...

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: I look this over later -- now I look you over.  If you want to be a spy, you gotta be in good condition.  I better examine you.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: There's something wrong -- I think I'm getting Whiteman's band.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: According to my watch it's four o'clock.  Now look -- a woman spy is a-gotta make love to men.  Come on -- let's see you make love...

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Now you feel my pulse.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: By the way, are you sure we need a spy?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Sure, we gotta have a spy.  If we no got a spy who's gonna tell the other side what we're doing?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Have you got any credentials?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: I don't go in much for modern art. Have you got anything by one of the old masters?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: I'm glad I didn't ask you for "Washington Crossing the Delaware".

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: We've gotta have somebody who knows how to get secrets from men.  You know how to make love?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: You ought to carry a spare.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: We're certainly living in a marvelous age.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: That's very funny... he certainly fooled me.  He'll make a good spy.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: If we can't use him as a spy, we can have him framed.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Say, that's a nice collection.  You oughta have a catalogue.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Let's take a look at number eighteen.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Say, she's all right.  You got-a her phone number?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: That's a funny one!

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: I think we can use you.  Here's a spy glass... go ahead and do some spying...

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: He's going to make a good spy... that's not bad for the first day.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: That's not bad for any day.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Maybe my eyes are bad - you take a look.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: You're right about that guy -- I think we've got something.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: I don't know about us, but I know he's-a got something...

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: This is all Firefly's fault -- that idiot, that fool...

Speaker: vera
Dialogue: I thought everything was working out fine.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Fine nothing!  I didn't want war... My plan was to marry Mrs. Teasdale and overthrow Firefly.

Speaker: vera
Dialogue: Maybe you can still win the old dame over -- why not try to --

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: I deeply regret the unfortunate affair with his Excellency, but his attitude left me no alternative...

Speaker: vera
Dialogue: Maybe the war can still be averted...

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Mrs. Teasdale, I'm willing to pocket my pride and do anything I can to make up with his Excellency.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: For you, I would do anything...

Speaker: vera
Dialogue: If only we can get his Excellency to listen to reason...

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Perhaps he will listen to you...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Why not come over here? -- You can come in the back way and no one'll see you...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: If I knew you were here I would've brought some cheese...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: So -- you've come to ask for clemency! I'll give the enemy no quarter -- not a dime...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Let him patch up his own breeches...

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: I'm sorry we lost our tempers... I'm willing to forget if you are.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Forget?  You ask me to forget... Why, my ancestors would rise from their graves... and I'd only have to bury them again... A Firefly never forgets...

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: I am willing to apologize...  I'm willing to do anything to prevent this war.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Nothing doing!!  I've taken a lease on the battlefield.  I'd lose my deposit, besides, I've already ordered the ammunition...

Speaker: vera
Dialogue: Oh, Your Excellency, isn't there something I can do?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Yes, but I'll talk to you about that when we're alone...

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: What I called you...  Why, what did I call you?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: I don't remember.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Oh -- you mean... worm?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: No, that wasn't it...

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Was it -- swine?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: No... it was a seven letter word.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Oh yes! -- UPSTART!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: That's it...

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: You RUNT!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: I still like UPSTART the best.

Speaker: vera
Dialogue: Oh, this is dreadful!  If you'll excuse me I'll go to my room...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Of course.  Who ever heard of calling off a war after ordering all the ammunition?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: The plans of war are in this envelope. I want you to take care of them -- no one will ever suspect you.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Guard them with your life... don't leave them out of your sight...  If the enemy gets those papers  we're lost.  If they don't get them, we're lost.  Can't you see what I'm trying to tell you?  I love you...   Mrs. Teasdale, you're the salt of the earth.  They don't come any better than you...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Well -- they might come better but they don't come any bigger... and the bigger the better.  The bigger the betta you've got on a horse, the more you lose, and speaking about horses, why don't you marry me. Come, come -- say yes and you'll never see me again.  I'll go 'way if it means your happiness...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Swell chance I've got taking you off your feet...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Gloria -- may I call you Gloria?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: You can call me Gloria too.  Gloria -- what a beautiful name.  When I was born my mother named me Gloria -- two minutes later she found out her mistake...

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Father...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Take a letter...

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Who to?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: None of your business...  Take another letter.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Eureka Ammunition Company -- Gentlemen -- Your shipment of sailor hats arrived this morning by freight --

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Eureka Ammunition Company, Gentlemen. Your shipment of sailor hats arrived this morning by freight.  Gloria, I could go for you in a big way. However, the rifles you sent were a little rusty and I don't say that to everybody.  Have not received last month's drawing account; how come your neck is like a swan.  Yours very truly...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: They'll know I mean business then they get that letter...  see that that gets out immediately and that goes for you too.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Gloria, much as I hate to leave, I'd be crazy to stay here.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: I'm not taking any more chances. You sit in the sidecar...

Speaker: usher
Dialogue: I'm sorry gentlemen - but you have the wrong seats.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: That's all right.  We're not enjoying ourselves anyway.

Speaker: usher
Dialogue: You belong in that box over there -

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Come on --

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Wait a minute... Mrs. Teasdale is in the box below.  The plans of war are in her purse -- you've got to get them -- I don't care how, but get them -- and when you do, bring them to 492 North Myrtle Road -- you'd better write that down.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Never mind His Excellency -- you gotta your pocketbook?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: I wanna powder my nose...

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: He's-a not missing anything.  He's in the dressing room with Vera Trentino.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: He could be playing solitaire, but I don't think so.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: What's the matter with you?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: I no gotta new-rosis.  My uncle he's- a got a flower shop -- he's-a gotta new-rosis.

Speaker: vera
Dialogue: I shall dance for you tonight as I've never danced before.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: This is a fine thing to be doing at my age.

Speaker: vera
Dialogue: Are you getting tired?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Not at all.  When I was a boy back on the farm I used to pump my own water.

Speaker: valet
Dialogue: Your love is waiting for you, my lord...

Speaker: hero
Dialogue: Fetch my hat - my hat - my hat --

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: He no got it ---

Speaker: vera
Dialogue: Are you sure you're not tired?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Tired!  I'd like to stretch this into a week -

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: That's all right.  I'll fix you right up.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: WHAT  ?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Don't bother me - I'm thinking -- What was that?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: What a fool I was to listen to your siren song and fall a helpless victim under the insidious spell of your irresistible charms --

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Not bad, eh?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: This is-a fine - you do a good job - you make-a no trouble and you waste- a no time.  Come on, we take-a the plans to the Ambassador.  You gotta the address?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Hands up!

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: You no gotta no gun.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Who said I had a gun... Gimme those plans, you paper snatchers --

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Here -- put these plans where no one will ever find them - sleep on them.

Speaker: vera
Dialogue: I'm sorry boys -- I did my best -- it's all my fault.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: It's not-a your fault.  It's-a his fault --  I fix it for you to getta the plans -- you getta the plans -- then you losa- a the plans -- now we no gotta the plans of war...

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: It's all your fault. Now we gotta steal the plans again -- You had 'em on you... you take a bath... and now we no gotta plans of war.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: You wait here -- I'll let you in.

Speaker: vera
Dialogue: Psst...

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: All right -- I'll meet you behind the drapes.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Come on, we gotta no time for that.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Wait a minute...  we make too much noise...  Turn on the radio so they can't hear what we're doing.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: What's-a matter, you crazy... ?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Come on, we gotta finish the job...

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Hello -- Police department... ? That fellow's  crazy...  we're in the house already...

Speaker: radio announcer
Dialogue: The Teasdale residence is located at 232 Poloma Drive...

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: That's it, you got it... Hurry up, if no get-a here soon, we can't wait...

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Hey, Skippy...

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: We gotta try the combination...  You gotta the combination?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: You come over here.  There are no burglars in my house.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Light it... Now we blow him up...

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Wait a minute... we gotta fix it so it don't make-a so much noise... What-a we do?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: That's fine... Now, nobody hear the noise.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: That woman is crazy... there are no burglars around here...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Ride through every village and town wake every citizen up hill and down tell them the enemy comes from afar with a hey-nonny-nonny and a ha-cha- char

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: There'll be two lamps in the steeple if they're coming by land and one lamp if they're coming by sea.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: They double-crossed me... they're coming by land and sea -- Be off, my lad!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Either there's a fly in the room or we've got a soldier in Africa.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: A dispatch from the front, sir.

Speaker: a general
Dialogue: Bad news, sir?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Bad news -- its disastrous!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Clear all wires...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: The enemy has taken Hill 25, throwing twelve Hill-billies out of work... Our front is exposed to the enemy -- we'll have to bring up the rear...  P.S.  Have misplaced flag of truce... look in upper lefthand drawer of my bureau...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Late again, eh?  You haven't been on time once since this war started...

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: I can't do it...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Why not?  You're the Secretary of War, aren't you?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Yes, but I'm not working for you any more.  I'm on the other side.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Is that so?  I used to think you were two-faced - but you can't be - or you wouldn't be wearing that one. Now - let's talk this thing over.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Now -- how many men you got in your army?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Well, we gotta one hundred thousand men.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: That's not fair -- we've only got fifty thousand.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: That's all right.  We let you have twenty-five thousand men -- and we both start even.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: That's the spirit -- fifty-fifty.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: No. Seventy-five -- seventy-five.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Well, we'll let that one go.  Now -- how many battalions you got?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: We gotta two battalions and one Frenchman.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: I wish you were still working for me, so I could ask you to resign. How're ya fixed for cavalry?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: I've gotta five thousand men but no horses.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: That's funny, we've got five thousand horses but no men.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: That's all right -- our men can ride your horses.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Not a bad idea.  If our horses get tired they can ride your men for a change.  Now, I don't mind letting you have our horses, but you must promise to put them through their maneuvers.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Oh, sure.  We have horse maneuvers every morning.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Acme Ammunition Company, eh?  How do you expect to win the war with shells that don't go off?  Now, if you were buying your stuff from me, you wouldn't have that trouble.  Eureka Ammunition is guaranteed to explode -- or your money back.  Let me show you some samples.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Load it up.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: With a gun like that you can kill some of your own men.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: That's-a pretty good.  I'll take a dozen of them.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Anything else?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Yes, one gross of bullets, two dozen hand-grenades, three kegs of powder -- and throw in some matches.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Fine.  We'll throw in the matches before we make the delivery.  By the way, how're you fixed for spys?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Fine.  We gotta him.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: So! -- He's on your side, too.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Well, with you two fellows on the other side, this country should have no trouble keeping the wolf from the door.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: Something must be done immediately. The soldiers are getting discouraged.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: There's only one thing to do... we must capture Firefly.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: But how?  It's a very dangerous undertaking.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Unless we can make Firefly our prisoner, we're lost.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Chicolini, you've come just in time. We need a man who's fearless, brave. A man who's willing to die, if necessary.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: All right -- I'll go out and find one.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: Firefly must be captured at any cost.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: That's easy, I'll get him for you wholesale.

Speaker: trentino
Dialogue: It must be done right away.

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: I can't do it right away.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: I got a date with a General's wife.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: Isn't that a little dangerous?

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Not unless you find it out.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Boys, I hate to do this, but if you generals want this war to continue you'll have to take a cut --

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: We can't afford to pay the money we've been paying. Now I don't want to lay anybody off.  My motto in this war is: - "Live and let live".

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Look!  That's-a Firefly's headquarters.  We catch him right now.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Gentlemen, the overhead is killing us.  Everything is going up.  If we don't watch ourselves, we'll come down with a crash.  Now -- all those in favor of taking a cut say "aye"...

Speaker: one general
Dialogue: But Your Excellency!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Carried unanimously.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Now go right out there and fight.  You go out there and relieve General Beauregard, and while you're at it, see what General Motors is doing.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Call him back -- he didn't salute me.

Speaker: zeppo
Dialogue: Father, he didn't salute you either.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Attention!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Go out there -- all of you -- and bring those generals back -- dead or alive.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Why don't those generals come back?

Speaker: zeppo
Dialogue: I'll call them.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Never mind, I'll go after them myself.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Hey, Junior!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Get my rifle.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: I'll get rid of them.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Take a letter.

Speaker: zeppo
Dialogue: To whom?

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: To whom it may concern...  Dear Gloria:  The air has done me a world of good.  I am five thousand feet above sea level speeding home to you.  Can you arrange to meet me at twenty-five hundred feet?  -- which is only asking you to meet me half way.  Don't be surprised if I drop in on you any minute... Your fun- loving Dictator.

Speaker: all
Dialogue: Hail, hail, Freedonia...  Land of the brave and free!

Speaker: zeppo
Dialogue: My dad is much too great for his position without a question.  I'd like to offer this with your permission as a suggestion: I really think he should be king!

Speaker: all
Dialogue: We really think he should be king!

Speaker: zeppo
Dialogue: I really think he should be king!

Speaker: all
Dialogue: He should be king!

Speaker: solo
Dialogue: And wear a crown and everything.

Speaker: all
Dialogue: And everything.

Speaker: solo
Dialogue: I really think he should be king!

Speaker: all
Dialogue: He should be king!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: From what I have been gathering, I think they think I should be king: I think they think I should be king!

Speaker: all
Dialogue: He should be king!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: And wear a crown and everything.

Speaker: all
Dialogue: And everything.  He should be king!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Although it would please me to govern the throng, suppose I were king and then everything went wrong.

Speaker: all
Dialogue: The king can do no wrong!  The king can do no wrong!

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Of course you're All aware a king must have an heir some one to pass the family name along will some one tell me where I'd ever get an heir if a king can do no wrong

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Suppose a pretty dame Into my castle came - And let us say that I was going strong.  She might be stuck on me, but what good would it be, if the king can do no wrong.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: King Solomon was game he gave each Girl his name to number them would make a list that long I'll bet his thousand wives led miserable lives if the king can do no wrong.

Speaker: all
Dialogue: We really think he should be king and wear a crown and everything.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: They think I should - They think I should - They think I should - They think I should be king.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: That was awfully good, I think I'll have a second helping...  waiter...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: If I don't stop eating I'll get indigestion...

Speaker: chico
Dialogue: Hey, she wants some salt...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Ambassador, how's the food?

Speaker: ambassador trentino
Dialogue: It's delicious, Your Excellency.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: That's all I wanted to know.

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: I couldn't eat another thing.  Ladies and gentlemen, I want to introduce to you a man who is a prince of good fellows, generous to a fault, his own worst enemy and a devil in his own hometown...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Thanks, I didn't expect to be called upon... However, in conclusion I want to tell you that I promised Mrs. Teasdale I'd marry her if we won the war.... Well, we won the war and I'm stuck... to the victor belongs the spoils...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: In union there is strength...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: I feel that we are taking a step in the right direction, and that's what I call balling the Jack...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: Now is not the time for political temporizing, all interests must be sacrificed for the common weal...

Speaker: groucho
Dialogue: All those who want to place their money on the wheel, step inside, faint heart never won fair lady... Money won't grow in your pocket like the hair on your head and now is the time for all good men to come to the aid of their party.
